issue_comments.body:
Guys

Seems important enough to go on Beta for sure.

Pj
On Mar 26, 2014 5:49 PM, "Vinay S Shenoy" notifications@github.com wrote:

> When books are fetched, book id, the user id associated with the book, the
> location id are all db row ids.
> 
> It's fine for the alpha lunch, but this is a must fix for the beta launch.
> It's important that the implementation details of the server are kept
> separate from the client. In the off chance that the DB row ids cannot be
> maintained during a migration, the clients will all fail unless they clear
> the app data and refetch everything, which is a big no-no for UX.
> 
> On Wed, Mar 26, 2014 at 5:40 PM, surendar notifications@github.com
> wrote:
> 
> > right now query is based on ids.(then i have to change everything based
> > on
> > it with is unnecesssary right now). even if we change the database we can
> > retain the ids that's not an issue. i think no apis right now is based
> > purely on ids for client side to work.
> > what are the exact uses cases you will be storing ids on client side and
> > sending to server
> > 
> > ## 
> > 
> > Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub<
> > https://github.com/barterli/barter.li/issues/29#issuecomment-38676015>
> > .
> 
> ## 
> 
> Vinay S Shenoy
> Software Engineer | Sourcebits LLC, Electronic City, Bangalore
> +91-9538122356 | vinaysshenoy@gmail.com
> LinkedIn : http://in.linkedin.com/in/vinaysshenoy
> 
> ## 
> 
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/barterli/barter.li/issues/29#issuecomment-38676707
> .

issues.title: 2 Issues being generated for the same bug reported.
issues.body: For each a bug being reported from the app there are 2 issues being generated. Can we resolve this from the client side?

issues.title: Genre of Books
issues.body:
Suri - Do check the Genre is received from GoodReads API or not. 

I think we must keep the genre of the books in our database for now. In future we may need it to help with discovery of books on our platform.

issues.title: 1:1 Chat
issues.body: I got a feedback from one of the students on our Indiegogo campaign that the if we have chat then the user authentication doesn't become a barrier and the platform can carry itself on its own!

issues.title: Report a bug/Suggest a feature/Love barter.li Feature
issues.body: Since it is a beta product focused primarily on getting some user feedback we should have a easily accessible way for the users to write back to us. We may use Freshdesk for now.

issues.title: Push Notification
issues.body:
1) When someone sends a request for Free/Barter/Sale book the info should be conveyed via a message which should be a push notification to the person.

2) Whenever a book on my wishlist comes in an area within 10 km of me then I should get a notification

issues.title: Book Search: When user searches for a particular book around him the query should run on our database as well as Good Reads.
issues.body: This is because if we do not have the book in our database around the person then it should be added to his wishlist.

issues.title: Profile: Do we need to show profile of a person via fb/Twitter details?? For people to see who they are going to meet
Books Category after adding books: Free, Barter, Sale, Read, Keep, Wish
issues.body:
Keep - is books I have but I will keep with my self. These will be private and no one can see them except me.

Read - is books available to read at that location only. e.g. a cafe which has 10 books to Read.

Wish - Wishlist

issues.title: Add preferred public location to exchange books (Your location is not shared/stored)
issues.body: We will use Four-Square APIs here to auto suggest. Again auto suggest should start with the 5 character and then after every 2 more characters.

issues.title: Add Book via scan/title/author/ISBN
issues.body: Both frontend and backend need this

issues.title: Login Authorization is via Facebook, Twitter
issues.body: I am guessing for the initial product (0.0) we may just have just Facebook/Twitter signin

issue_comments.body: Basically the wishlist should add every searched book (which wasn't in our database) to the wishlist and the person should have an option to remove it by one click.

Yes I agree. It will be a good idea to run this through a data base expert.

1) If the user changes his location then all his books should be auto-reassigned the location.

Explain me further if Freshdesk doesn't have a native android support. If this is the case then lets choose helpshift. HS says they have a limit of 10k MAUs per month on free account.

Prasun
Suren! Communication 101 :)

The solution is to have a chat enabled so that there is no exchange of email ID's. This way we can still reduce the privacy risk. Having more profile info can also help reduce stalkers on the platform!

The blue color pin for 'self location' is not tappable as it is your current location not a public location. So it should be changed to a blue dot which we regularly see on the Google maps for our own location.
Okay this is a great feedback from our users.

Hey this is already implemented. We will send a list item tomorrow at
noon. Please do go through the app and code by then.
On Jun 20, 2014 10:20 PM, "amoghbl1" notifications@github.com wrote:

> Do we need this? I can implement it if we do!
> 
> On Fri, Jun 20, 2014 at 9:50 PM, barter notifications@github.com wrote:
> 
> > Can we add "rate us" in left menu.. which will take us to play store?
> > 
> > —
> > Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> > https://github.com/barterli/barter.li/issues/148.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/barterli/barter.li/issues/148#issuecomment-46700788.
We believe you have failed to choose your preferred location to barter books. Is that the case?
This is an important feature request. I have seen it 5-6th time now. Few people asked me for it in person and few have asked for it via feature request.
Check if you have GPS on. Add a preferred location for book exchange. Only then you can add books.
Its already there...

issues.title: Setting up the development environment
issues.body:
Hi
I wanted to see how this thing is working and was looking for some inspirations from the repo. But I am unable to make this thing run as not all the migration files are present, and hence the migrations are broken..Can anyone guide me in resolving this and setting up the development environment?
Thanks

issue_comments.body: Thanks. :)

issues.title: create  proper documentation
issues.body:
i have decided to use yard for documentation
http://yardoc.org/

issues.title: Possible privacy issue with Contact user.
issues.body: In the current plan, when a particular user find a book he wants to buy/barter/whatever, how does he contact? Is it in-app where he types in the message, and it goes to server, and from server to the recipient's mail? Or directly from the sender's phone to the recipient's mail Id? If the latter case, we should switch to the earlier case, since it could end up exposing the recipient's email ID to the sender, which shouldn't happen.

issue_comments.body: Look at Helpshift(http://www.helpshift.com/) also. They support native web/Android/iOS support.
Was for barter.li android version. Am transferring and closing the issue here.
Was for Android version. Am closing this.

About that, have we decided how to go about it? I sent some links with XMPP for Rails, and I feel it is the best choice. AFAIK, Freshdesk and Helpshift provide chat for customer support, i.e., user to customer support, but not user-to-user.
Oh, the endpoint is http://developer.github.com/v3/issues/#create-an-issue
Even when searching books, the location parameter should be updated for this format.
In miles? Can we use in metres instead? User might zoom to very low level in Map.

No, I'm not asking for postal code and CC. That's just an example.

What is important for me are the following fields - id, fq_id(if exists), name, address, lat, lng

This is because when displaying search results, I can add a little line to every search result -  "find at UB City, Vittal Mallya Road".

If you can get the Street, and Cross Street from FQ as well, that will be awesome too. The thing is, I won't be reverse geododing from the lat/lng until the user goes into book details, to prevent unecessary API calls. Whatever you can give me in server response will be great as it will make the UX smooth.
Hmm. I can send 0. values for km?
Yeah, it's not a priority. As long as we can search as low as 1 km, it should be more than enough for now.

Also one more issue. Right now, it requires search parameter. Can you make that also optional? It should work like this - 
- search,lat,long,radius -> Return all books matching the name, centered at lat/lng/ within radius km
- lat,long,radius - Return all books centered at lat/long within radius km
- search, but one of the other parameters - discard the other params, keep only the search
- nothing - return books according to rating or something(in future, check if you can user's location from IP address and use that instead)

For the home screen, we need something to show on first launch. For that, we require the second form of the API.

Also, what is the limit on the items returning from API. We need to add a limit so that the response doesn't take too much time. In future, we'll need to add pagination.

That's not a good way, because the tags are hardcoded on client end. The flow with this will cause a lot of issues, for example, if pulling tags fails.

If you can tell me which tag id are associated with which barter type is associated with which tag, I can add it into the app. In any case, the types of tags will not change often.
Pushed to server? I'm still getting null :-)

That's ok, but we won't be able to show the preferred location on the home
page for books. This is what we can do -
1. If user sets preferred location using Foursquare venues, it's no
   problem because we will get all those details with foursquare objects
2. If user decides to use custom location for preferred location, the
   client will reverse geocode it.

In either case, the client will have the full address at the time of
setting the preferred location. The client can send this info to you along
with lat/long when setting user preferred location. If we do this, there
won't be any problem in sending this along with book info, right? Because
user preferred location will be same as book preferred location.

The same procedure can be followed in future when we enable individual
preferred locations for books.

Nope. But the problem will happen if database migration is done, let''s
say, switching servers or changing the underlying database.

The DB row ids for individual user Ids might change, which will render the
clients unoperable. If we instead generate string ids separately, the
database on server end can be separated from the app.

When books are fetched, book id, the user id associated with the book, the
location id are all db row ids.

It's fine for the alpha lunch, but this is a must fix for the beta launch.
It's important that the implementation details of the server are kept
separate from the client. In the off chance that the DB row ids cannot be
maintained during a migration, the clients will all fail unless they clear
the app data and refetch everything, which is a big no-no for UX.

Then it has no difference at all. The db row id shouldn't be communicated
in the API response in any form. ID should be totally disconnected from row
ID.

As for the uniqueness constraint, just add a uniqueness constraint to the
field in the DB. Generate the random string id, and save it. Second, as
long as your ID generation algorithm is proper, you shouldn't need to worry
about uniqueness. We know that the id will be generated only during user
creation. If that's the case, the email ID will be unique as we know it
already isn't there in the DB. The id for the user can be an SHA1 hash of
the email id as it's only used for identification, not authentication.

Software Engineer | Sourcebits LLC, Electronic City, Bangalore

Can you point me to some documentation where this is mentioned? In every
web service I've integrated so far, email is used only when sign in, create
user or reset password.

For others, they only require the auth token, nothing else.
On Mar 28, 2014 2:58 PM, "surendar" notifications@github.com wrote:

> normally email is used in this cases not ids.
> 
> ## 
> 
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/barterli/barter.li/issues/35#issuecomment-38901133
> .

The thing is, it's not a best practice. The client shouldn't care what
implementation the server has, one when you sent the db row id to client,
you are exposing some of that implementation to client.

Second, the identifier should be separated from the implementation again.
The identifier is what will keep the server->client binding intact even if
the underlying database has changed. If you use even a part of the
identifier to directly access the database, there is a chance of failure.
And I'm sure there will be security issues as well if you directly give the
row id.

You can check most of the API providers. Facebook, Google, Twitter,
Foursquare, none of them do this way.

Nope. This was a conscious decision we took to keep the user experience consistent. We will be adding more content and things to do i your current location soon.
Nope. The app focuses on creating a community of book lovers and bibliophiles in different locations.

This is how it is designed. Chat messages are stored locally on the device
and not on our servers. We are working on adding features to fix this,
specifically
- Allowing the user to connect the app to his Google Drive/Dropbox account
  and backup his chat messages there.

In the meantime, it's evident that we need to indicate that logging out
will cause the chat messages stored locally to be lost.
